bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J. McKeen Cattell, December 2, 1919

div1.p: Carter informs Cattell that he published two papers on the incubation of yellow fever, which were the basis of Reed's experiments with the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J. McKeen Cattell, December 2, 1919
div1.opener:
Mis:
Original work.
Baltimore, Md.
December 2, 1919.
Professor J. McKeen Cattell,
Garrison-on-Hudson, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Cattell:
div1.p:
I am enclosing a Circular Letter from the Bureau. I do not
know whether it applies to anything I have done or not. I must
leave you to be the judge.

I published two papers on The Extrinsic Incubation of Yellow
Fever in 1900, which were the basis of Read's Quemados experiments
and on which Major Ross Sir) Ronald Ross made application for the Nobel Prize
for Medical Research jointly for myself and Carlos Finlay of Havana.

In 1916, associated with LePrince and Griffitts, some observations
were published on the occurrence and biology of certain species of
Anopheles mosquitoes--of no great importance entomologically, but of
very great importance in the control of malaria.

I do not know whether the first would be considered an ”investiga-
tion in an exact science.“ The second probably is, but is of very
much smaller importance. especially pananenomological stand
point
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. 1 enclosure.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
Please return Circular Letter for filing.
